texts.definition: The effects of actions and events in games do not occur directly after the actions or events have started.
markups: <style="Definition">The effects of actions and events in games do not occur directly after the actions or events have started.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> are those effects that are explicitly dictated by the rules in the game but take place some noticeable time after the actions and events that caused them; effects that are the results of combined actions or are unexpected or unplanned do not qualify as <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style>, even if the effects take place after some actions or events have taken place.

The effect of placing bets in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> does not become apparent until a player folds or players show their card hands. The activation of the most powerful weapons in first-person shooters such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> often takes some time from activation to the time it fires, usually to balance them somewhat against the other weapons in the game.

Building manufactories in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> take five years in game time where each turn or tick represents a day; in contrast, the amount of time between planting seeds in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> until they can be harvested can take several real world days.

It is believed that there was a <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effect</style> before one could capture pieces in the ancient Roman game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ludus%20Latrunculorum">Ludus Latrunculorum</link></style>.

A simple way to create <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> with <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> is to require <style="Link"><link="development-time">Development Time</link></style> for initiated actions or simply make them <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style>. Others ways to introduce <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> into games include <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, or modulating how <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> function. While <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style> are usually done immediately they can be modulated to make use of <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style>.

Besides the actual cause for the delay, primary design choices for <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> are if players should be aware of when the effects will occur and how the period of delay is determined. Showing when effects will take place is usually done through <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style>, even when they are predetermined through <style="Link"><link="development-time">Development Time</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can be used to make information about when the <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> occur unknown, but so can other ways involving <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style>.

Making actions have <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> opens up some additional design possibilities. One is to create <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> between different actions by having the more powerful actions take a longer time to perform. Another is to make them possible interrupt, that is making the actions into <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>, or make it possible to avoid the effects - this is quite often applied to <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>. This is done in some cases of <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, e.g. this is believed to be the case for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ludus%20Latrunculorum">Ludus Latrunculorum</link></style>, to allow the other player a chance to respond. A third, which can be used to increase <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, is to combine them to the structures of <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> can make people have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and feel that they have <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style> without requiring any other aspects of the game, this makes the pattern useful for modulate <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quick%20Games">Quick Games</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> often produce <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> for those aware of them, especially if they are part of <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>. The more precise information about the <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> players have, e.g. by knowing when they take place due to being created through <style="Link"><link="development-time">Development Time</link></style>, the more <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> they provide, and this encouraged <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>. When <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> are absent, it instead provides players the possibility to start feeling <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style> before the outcome is shown. Although <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> can influence <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> in these ways, having sufficiently long <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> may in return make <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> be harder to have since the context for the outcome can have changed. Even so, understanding how <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> work is a form of <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>.

The wait for the effects to take place is a form of <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> once the events or actions that cause the <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> have been done, and waiting for them can create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, especially when combined with <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style>. Players may also be able to use <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> to create <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> by efficiently <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> actions. Fixed periods of delay give players the chance to use <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> to do better <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>. If the periods of delay are random, or if players do not have knowledge of the periods of delay, this can turn the use of other actions into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> choices if their success depends on the <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style>. <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> that can be interrupted also give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations.

When a part of the <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> is waiting for other players to do actions, as is the case when the pattern is use to change <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>, it gives rise <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style> (with <style="Link"><link="individual-rewards">Individual Rewards</link></style> in the case of <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style>) and the possibility of <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>.  For games with long enough waiting times and <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay or <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> gives <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> can somewhat mitigate that <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> make <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> impossible. However, the <style="CurrentLink">Delayed Effects</style> make any potential <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> of the <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> difficult to be aware of.
